text:
In this video, we will take a quick tour of the
key capabilities of Amazon CodeWhisperer.

With CodeWhisperer, you can generate 
code suggestions that help you get

more done-faster, scan code to identify 
security vulnerabilities, and flag or filter

suggestions that are similar 
to open source training data.

Although CodeWhisperer supports many
programming languages and development

environments, we will demonstrate its functionality 
using Python in Visual Studio Code (or VS Code).

Let’s navigate to the AWS Toolkit extension 
panel, where we can start CodeWhisperer.

We’ll authenticate with our AWS 
Builder ID to turn on CodeWhisperer.

CodeWhisperer is now activated and 
will provide code suggestions in your
code editor window as you type.
Let’s begin by writing a comment.

We’ll tell CodeWhisperer to create a 
function that extracts only the second
field from a CSV file and puts it in a list.

CodeWhisperer suggested multiple 
functions, which we can cycle through
using the arrow keys on our keyboard.

To accept a recommendation, 
we can use our Tab key.
Let’s do that now.
Let’s pass a CSV file to the function to test it.

The function generated by CodeWhisperer 
returned only the second field.

CodeWhisperer is a general-purpose 
coding companion that is also optimized

for popular AWS services such 
as Amazon S3 so that it generates

high-quality suggestions that 
incorporate AWS best practices.

Let’s write a comment asking for a 
function to create an Amazon S3 bucket.
Let's use this suggestion.

Now, let’s create a function 
to upload files to that bucket.

Using CodeWhisperer, we now have two functions 
that follow best practices for using AWS Service

APIs without our needing to spend a lot 
of time looking through the documentation.

Next, we’ll use CodeWhisperer to scan 
for security vulnerabilities in our code.
Let’s open the file we want to investigate.
Now let’s run the security scan.

CodeWhisperer has detected 
two security issues in this file.

On the Problems tab, we can click 
each issue to locate it in the code.

We can hover over the highlighted code
to review the suggested remediation.

In this example, unencrypted AWS credentials 
are logged, which is a security vulnerability.
Let’s rewrite the code to fix the vulnerability.
Let’s view the second issue.

CodeWhisperer is telling us to set the 
AuthenticateOnUnsubcribe flag to True.
Let’s fix that.

Now that both issues have been 
addressed, let’s re-scan the file.

The security scan completed 
with no detected issues.

Next, let’s view an example of 
CodeWhisperer’s reference tracking ability.

We want to implement a function 
to create a DynamoDB table.

The first code suggestion is flagged by the 
reference tracker as being under MIT license.

The next suggestion references 
code under Apache-2.0 license.
We’ll accept this flagged code.

CodeWhisperer automatically logged the
reference with the license information

we need so we can add proper 
license and attribution to our code.

At any time, we can pause automatic 
code suggestions from CodeWhisperer

by going to the extension 
panel and setting that option.

We can still trigger the CodeWhisperer 
suggestions manually by using the

Option + C key combination on a Mac, 
or ALT + C key combination on Windows.

You’ve just seen how to use some of the 
key capabilities of Amazon CodeWhisperer.

You can learn more about Amazon CodeWhisperer 
by visiting aws.amazon.com/codewhisperer.
Thanks for watching. Now it’s your turn to try.
